statement.tex: %text If \[ y = 3\cos(\log x) + 4\sin(\log x)\], then show that \[ x\cdot \frac{d^2 y}{dx^2} + x\cdot \frac{dy}{dx} + y = 0 \] %
\\ \textbf{Let's get clever - Part I} \\ %text In which of the figures below are the values of \underline\text{$\cos\phi$ and $\sin\phi$} written correctly? %
\\ %text \textbf{Let's get clever - Part II} Given an angle $\phi$ such that $\cos\phi = \frac{3}{5}$, \underline\text{which of the following is true}? %
\\ %text Given that $y = 5\cdot\cos\left(\log x - \phi\right)$, which of the following is true? %
\\ %text \underline\text{Check our work} Given $\frac{dy}{dx}$ and $\frac{d^2 y}{dx^2}$ from the last step, is the work done below correct? %

reason.tex:
%text In the given \underline\text{right-angled} triangle, the hypotenuse is simply $\sqrt{3^2+4^2} = 5$
Therefore, $\cos\phi = \frac{3}{5}$ and $\sin\phi=\frac{4}{5}$. %

\begin{align} y &= 3\cos(\log x) + 4\sin(\log x) \\ &= 5\cdot\left[ \frac{3}{5}\cdot \cos(\log x) + \frac{4}{5}\cdot \sin(\log x)\right] \\ &= 5\cdot\left[ \cos\phi\cdot\cos(\log x) + \sin\phi\cdot\sin(\log x)\right] \\ &= 5\cdot\underbrace{\cos\left( \log x - \phi \right)}_{\cos\left(A-B\right) = \cos A\cos B + \sin A\sin B} \end{align} \\ %text
\underline\text{The simpler expression for $y$} should make subsequent work easier.
And remember, \underline\text{$\phi$ is a constant}! %

\begin{align} y &= 5\cdot\cos\left( \log x - \phi \right) \\ \implies \frac{dy}{dx} &= 5\cdot\underbrace{\left[ -\sin\left(\log x - \phi\right) \cdot \frac{d}{dx}\log x\right]}_{\text{Chain Rule}}\\ &= -\frac{5}{x}\cdot\sin\left(\log x-\phi \right) \\ \therefore \frac{d^2 y}{dx^2} = -5&\underbrace{\left[ \frac{x\overbrace{\cos(\log x-\phi)\frac{1}{x}}^{\text{Chain Rule}}-\sin(\log x - \phi)}{x^2} \right]}_{\text{Quotient Rule}}\\ = \frac{5}{x^2}&\sin\left( \log x - \phi\right) -\frac{5}{x^2}\cos\left( \log x -\phi \right) \end{align}
%text Look for $y$ and $\frac{dy}{dx}$ in the expression for $\frac{d^2 y}{dx^2}$. The rest is just algebra. %
